"There are confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Afghanistan. National airports are open.  The Ministry of Public Health requires a negative PCR test, conducted within 96 hours of travel, for all incoming passengers.    People arriving from other countries and who do not show symptoms of COVID-19 are advised to self-quarantine at home for 14 days.  If you have any symptoms, you are instructed to contact the Ministry of Public Health and seek care."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210202072319/https://af.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grant for individuals directly affected by the pandemic and full interest waiver on loans contracted since April 10, 2020 until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waiver will continue until March 2021.    IMF Archive Today: http://archive.today/bZZSM

The first consignment of the vaccine will arrive in the country very soon.  The plan is to vaccinate all the people together, so we will roll out the nationwide vaccination program only when we have sufficient doses for all the targetted population.  Once we have the required number of doses, our plan is to vaccinate the entire population in their respective communities, gewogs and chiwogs in one week. We are well on track with health facilities and human resource planning. That time, movement of people will be stopped for one week.  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/18-01-21-%f0%9d%90%92%f0%9d%90%9a%f0%9d%90%a5%f0%9d%90%a2%f0%9d%90%9e%f0%9d%90%a7%f0%9d%90%ad-%f0%9d%90%a9%f0%9d%90%a8%f0%9d%90%a2%f0%9d%90%a7%f0%9d%90%ad%f0%9d%90%ac-%f0%9d%90%9f%f0%9d%90%ab/

"**Schools re-open today except in Western Province, isolated areas**  Education Minister Prof. G. L. Peris yesterday said that schools will be reopened for grade 2–13 students in all parts of the country today except schools in the Western province and isolated areas. He said that the Ministry arrived at this decision after taking all measures to ensure the health security of the students. Addressing a press conference in Colombo yesterday, the Minister said that reopening of schools from Grade 2 – 13 will take place today on a plan made by the Ministry."    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210119024202/https://dailynews.lk/2021/01/11/local/238439/schools-re-open-today-except-western-province-isolated-areas-minister

There are 1, 576 schools in the WP and 900 schools are eligible to open according to the health guidelines, he said."    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126055628/http://www.dailymirror.lk/breaking_news/Schools-except-in-isolated-areas-in-WP-open-tomorrow-Minister/108-204384

Multiple  new reports from Jan 3 suggest that random Rapid Antigen Tests are being conducted and available at Fish Stalls in the Western Province (the country's capital Colombo is in the Western Province):   - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126065207/https://colombogazette.com/2021/01/03/rapid-antigen-tests-conducted-at-fish-stalls-in-western-province/  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126065251/https://www.newsradio.lk/local/random-tests-to-be-conducted-at-fish-stalls-markets/

"Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Sri Lanka? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  S. citizens can obtain a COVID-19 test in Sri Lanka at any private hospital. The average cost per test is 9,000-13,000 Sri Lankan Rupees (approximately $50-$70).  Test results are forwarded via e-mail."   - https://web.archive.org/web/20210125130941/https://lk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Additionally, multiple  new reports from Jan 3 suggest that random Rapid Antigen Tests are being conducted at Fish Stalls in the Western Province (the country's capital Colombo is in the Western Province):   - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126065207/https://colombogazette.com/2021/01/03/rapid-antigen-tests-conducted-at-fish-stalls-in-western-province/  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126065251/https://www.newsradio.lk/local/random-tests-to-be-conducted-at-fish-stalls-markets/

Sri Lanka continues to employ a comprehensive contact tracing and isolation for its COVID 19 clusters. Targeted areas are put under (and removed) from isolation on a (near-) daily basis -- see notes for C2 through mid-December 2020 to mid-January 2021 for archived Press Releases for Isolation Area updates.    Additionally, based on a Dec 1 2020 news reports it seems that PCR and Rapid Antigen testing was expanded beyond just govt. institutes conducting them, to private workplaces conducting them regularly: "The contacts of a Covid-19 positive employee at the workplace can be referred to Rapid Antigen Tests." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126072203/http://www.adaderana.lk/news/69606/guidelines-for-private-sector-on-carrying-out-rapid-antigen-tests    The full set of Govt issued guidelines as reported in the news report are available below:    "All employees should undergo mandatory Covid-19 symptom screening daily at the entrance of the workplace. In addition to checking the temperature.  • Any employee identified with symptoms suspicious of Covid-19 at the screening should be subjected to Rapid Antigen Test.  • A name list of employees undergoing this test and the test result must be submitted to the Epidemiology Unit (chiefepid@health.gov.lk), Regional Epidemiologist in the district and the area MOH on a daily basis.  • If the Rapid Antigen Test is positive, the Epidemiology Unit, area MOH and Regional Epidemiologist must be informed and the treatment protocol should be initiated.  • If the Rapid Antigen Test is negative, the employee should be subjected to PCR testing and should not involve in duties until results are available.  • If the PCR test is positive, the notification process (informing the Epidemiology Unit, Regional Epidemiologist and the area MOH) must be followed and the treatment protocol should be initiated.  • If the test result is negative, the employee should remain at the place of residence until the episode is settled.  • However, if the symptoms are worsening, the employee must be advised to inform the appointed focal point at the enterprise. The focal point should inform the area MOH for necessary action.  • The contacts of a Covid-19 positive employee at the workplace can be referred to Rapid Antigen Tests.  • The factories under the purview of the Board of Investment (BOI) and the Export Development Board (EDB) are instructed to conduct PCR tests as per health recommendations. However, if a factory is located in a high-risk area for Covid-19, 10 per cent of its employees can be directed to Rapid Antigen Tests."

"PCR or antigen tests on individuals not wearing face masks"  "Police Spokesman, Deputy Inspector General (DIG) Ajith Rohana said that more people have been detected on the streets without face masks.    He said that while legal action will be taken on those not wearing face masks in public, PCR or antigen tests will be conducted on them from today (Tuesday).    “You must wear a face mask when moving around in a public place or an area where the public also gather,” he said."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126064542/https://colombogazette.com/2021/01/05/pcr-or-antigen-tests-on-individuals-not-wearing-face-masks/

Jan 18 2021: Pakistan Today: "The federal Government on Friday extended the date for reopening of primary and middle schools (Class 1-8) from January 25 to February 1 after scrutiny of current Covid-19 situation in order to ensure safety of students.. Shafqat said that the government’s prior decision (to reopen schools) will be followed regarding reopening of high-and intermediate-level schools (9-12) from January 18, while universities will reopen from February 1." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126080730/https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2021/01/15/primary-middle-schools-to-remain-closed-till-feb-1-shafqat/    "Punjab Schools To Open From Jan 18, Universities From Feb 1: Minister" - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126080625/https://whenwherehow.pk/2021/01/04/punjab-schools-to-open-from-jan-18-universities-from-feb-1-minister/    "Pakistan Schools Begin Phased Reopening ... Pakistan has started reopening schools in phases after about two months of closure despite a steady increase in infections and fatalities from the coronavirus. Authorities said in the first phase, classes for senior grade students will reopen, while junior class will be reopened from February 1st." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126080912/https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/pakistan-news/pakistan-schools-begin-phased-reopening.html

No change from the policy as reported on Jan 18, 2021: https://web.archive.org/web/20210126080730/https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2021/01/15/primary-middle-schools-to-remain-closed-till-feb-1-shafqat/

"Islamabad: All the educational institutions in Pakistan — from nursery classes to university  — are opening from Monday February 1, raising fears of a spike in cases of COVID-19 in case Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) are not followed." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210202081402/https://gulfnews.com/world/asia/pakistan/pakistan-set-to-open-educational-institutions-from-monday-1.76859631

Given that the economy is generally open, there seem to be no active measures to stop public transportation.

Given that the economy is generally open, there seem to be no active measures to stop public transportation.    Is public transportation operating? [Yes]  According to the Government of Pakistan, individuals using public transportation – trains or buses – should wear facemasks and keep a distance of at least six feet from other individuals. - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"There are government “smart” lockdowns (i.e., small localities, such as a building with multiple units, streets, and small neighborhoods, may be sealed to limit the spread of the coronavirus.). Hours of operation for businesses may be reduced in localities under these targeted lockdowns."  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    "The economy is predominantly open, with services such as grocery stores and other businesses operational.  Some streets, neighborhoods, and commercial zones are currently under lockdown in Pakistan’s major cities.  Areas identified by authorities as COVID-19 “hotspots” could be locked down without advance notice"
"Is a curfew in place? [No]  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? [No]"    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? [No]    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? [Yes]  Pakistan’s Ministry of National Health Services, Regulation, and Coordination issued updated guidelines for arriving passengers on January 5. The Pakistani Civil Aviation Authority’s (PCAA) latest implementation guidelines began November 20.  On January 5 the PCAA released new guidelines for travelers arriving from the UK and South Africa.  Keep current on your airline’s requirements for initiating a journey to Pakistan.  All passengers are required to install and register on the Pass Track app prior to issuance of boarding pass to Pakistan at point of original embarkation (available for Android and Apple devices).  Passengers who do not have android/Apple phones and are unable to download the Pass Track app will need to enter their data on an accessible web-based form and provide a paper printout of the same prior to issuance of boarding pass to Pakistan at point of original embarkation.  All passengers will also have to fill out a health declaration form (HDF) before landing (see Questionnaire for Travelers).  Countries are categorized into Category A, B, or C primarily based on epidemiological risk assessment, reviewed every two weeks by the Ministry of National Health Services, Regulations, and Coordination.  Travelers arriving from Category A countries:  No COVID-19 RT-PCR (real-time, reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction) test required before or after travel.  Travelers arriving from Category B countries (on January 20, 2021 the United States falls under this category):  Show proof of a negative RT-PCR test result taken within 96 hours of commencement of original travel.  Travelers arriving from Category C countries:  Show proof of a negative RT-PCR test result taken within 96 hours of commencement of original travel. All arriving from a Category C country will also take a mandatory RT-PCR test upon arrival in Pakistan.  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? [Yes]  Upon arrival, all travelers will line up six feet (two meters) apart and undergo thermo-screening by thermo-guns and/or thermo-scanners.  Detailed information for arriving passengers is available in the Guidelines for International Passengers Arriving at Airports in Pakistan.  For the most up-to-date information regarding visa extensions for residents and/or tourists, please visit here."    "Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? [No]  Symptomatic travelers will be required to take a COVID-19 RT-PCR test and its results submitted to the designated Pakistani authorities within 48 hours of arrival.  In cases found positive for COVID-19 based on a test upon arrival, travelers may be required to comply with isolation procedures.  Asymptomatic travelers should be provided with written instructions and guidelines for home quarantine for 14 days."    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? [Yes]  Upon arrival, all travelers will line up six feet (two meters) apart and undergo thermo-screening by thermo-guns and/or thermo-scanners.    [travelers from certain countries are required to] Show proof of a negative RT-PCR test result taken within 96 hours of commencement of original travel."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Tests are available for anyone symptomatic. Anyone asymptomatic can also get tested but need to cite specific circumstances.     "Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in [Pakistan]? [Yes] Both viral antigen and RT-PCR tests are available.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? [Yes] Currently labs are regularly able to provide COVID-19 test results within the required timeframe.  Testing is currently available both to individuals with symptoms as well as for asymptomatic individuals who need a test for administrative reasons, such as for preflight."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Tests seem to be available for any one with symptoms. However, asymptomatic individuals can also request a test for "administrative reasons, such as for preflight". Given the narrow scope for asymptomatic individuals to get a tested, i am marking this as a 2 (instead of a 3)    "Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Pakistan? Yes.  Both viral antigen and RT-PCR tests are available.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes.  Currently labs are regularly able to provide COVID-19 test results within the required timeframe.  Testing is currently available both to individuals with symptoms as well as for asymptomatic individuals who need a test for administrative reasons, such as for preflight." https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

In Pakistan, provinces carry out contact tracing, but the process is assisted and centrally collated, and the NCOC (National Command Operation Center) is aware of the tests done for potentially infected persons and as part of contact tracing. (source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210126092232/https://thediplomat.com/2020/07/inside-pakistans-covid-19-contact-tracing/)    Among the recent Standard Operating Procedures by the NCOC (at https://ncoc.gov.pk/sop.php; https://web.archive.org/web/20210126092351/https://ncoc.gov.pk/sop.php) the definition of Frontline Workers was formally established: https://web.archive.org/web/20210126091210/https://ncoc.gov.pk/sop/80.%20Approved%20Definition%20-%20FLHCWs%20FS.pdf  Amongst the criteria, point 2 was: "b. Public health staff involved with test, track and quarantine. These are staff visiting patients at home, collecting data and samples from home."  --- Indicating that testing and tracking is a key component of Pakistan's health infrastructure and COVID19 response.    Further, among the recent notices NCOC also released a detailed guidance sheet for how to identify "contact" and track symptomatic and asymptomatic cases for incoming International Passengers - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126091949/https://ncoc.gov.pk/sop/79.%2020210105%20International%20Passengers%20Arriving%20at%20Airports%20in%20Pakistan_4805.pdf (dated: Jan 5 2021)    finally, from the later part of 2020,  (dated Sep 26 2020), NCOC release guidelines for how to "Home Quarantine during COVID 19 Out-break", in which it lays out steps to identify "contacts" during a home quarantine, and proceed with testing for those who come in "contact" with COVID-19. -- https://web.archive.org/web/20210126092010/https://ncoc.gov.pk/sop/66.%2020200926%20Guidelines%20for%20Home%20Quarantine%20for%20Contacts%20and%20International%20Travelers_0403.pdf

No change from prior notes. NCOC continue to engage in coordinating contact tracing functions carried out by local provinces in Pakistan.    In Pakistan, provinces carry out contact tracing, but the process is assisted and centrally collated, and the NCOC (National Command Operation Center) is aware of the tests done for potentially infected persons and as part of contact tracing. (source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210126092232/https://thediplomat.com/2020/07/inside-pakistans-covid-19-contact-tracing/)
"Masks are required to be worn when in public, and violators could be fined by law enforcement." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in this general policy since Oct: "The Pakistan National Command and Operation Centre (NCOC) announced October 28, 2020, that, effective immediately, to prevent the spread of COVID-19, masks must be worn when in public, countrywide. Islamabad Capital Territory (ICT) ordered masks must be worn in public places, including bazaars, shopping malls, and restaurants or while using public transport.  ICT’s announcement warns those not following the order may be subject to legal action." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
"Vaccines are currently not available in Pakistan, as the country has not yet procured these." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Has the Government of Pakistan approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? [Yes] The Government of Pakistan has approved two vaccines for emergency use, AstraZeneca and SinoPharm.  Vaccines are currently not available in Pakistan, as the country has not yet procured these    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
